posts.post_content: @djflo: The Mindslaver combo does work. If I Intuition for Mindslaver, Life from the Loam and Academy Ruins, then I end up with Life from the Loam either in my hand or my graveyard, in which case I dredge it. Then I cast it to get Academy Ruins, unless you gave me Academy Ruins already. Then I use Academy Ruins to get Mindslaver, unless you gave me Mindslaver already. It may take up to 2 turns, but the lock *is* coming eventually.
posts.html:
@djflo: The Mindslaver combo does work. If I Intuition for Mindslaver, Life from the Loam and Academy Ruins, then I end up with Life from the Loam either in my hand or my graveyard, in which case I dredge it. Then I cast it to get Academy Ruins, unless you gave me Academy Ruins already. Then I use Academy Ruins to get Mindslaver, unless you gave me Mindslaver already. It may take up to 2 turns, but the lock is coming eventually.

Posted By: alextfish (6/16/2011 7:00:06 AM)

posts.post_content:
@djflo: Boneclub's first combo does work. Whatever card you get can be used to get the Mindslaver (play Life from the Loam to get the Ruins, which lets you get the Mindslaver) and he can always dredge the Life from the Loam to ensure he has the Academy Ruins.   
  
The second one doesn't work, however. The opponent chooses Vampire Hexmage, and Dark Depths and Grim Discovery both go into the graveyard.

Posted By: MithosFall (10/10/2012 4:49:33 PM)

posts.post_content:
I suspect whoever first drafted this card imagined a [Gifts Ungiven](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gifts Ungiven)-type "with different names" clause implied, and then that never made it to final production.  
  
The combo with [Accumulated Knowledge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Accumulated Knowledge) isn't as nice as it seems at first. For ![3](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=3&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol)![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol), you're drawing three cards. Even split over two turns, that's only worthwhile if you're confident you'll draw the fourth AK in your deck. (Or a [Snapcaster Mage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Snapcaster Mage).)  
  
I'm pretty sure the only time I don't cast this to go find three copies of a card is in a [Gifts Ungiven](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gifts Ungiven) deck, but if you're looking to build a deck around this card instead of using it to tutor up three copies of a pre-established combo piece, notice Intuition is actually much better as a double [Entomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Entomb). Badass #1 + Badass #2 + [Unburial Rites](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unburial Rites), for example. If you're worried about getting the wrong thing in the graveyard, consider including a [Phantasmago](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phantasmago)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
I suspect whoever first drafted this card imagined a Gifts Ungiven-type "with different names" clause implied, and then that never made it to final production.

The combo with Accumulated Knowledge isn't as nice as it seems at first. For , you're drawing three cards. Even split over two turns, that's only worthwhile if you're confident you'll draw the fourth AK in your deck. (Or a Snapcaster Mage.)

I'm pretty sure the only time I don't cast this to go find three copies of a card is in a Gifts Ungiven deck, but if you're looking to build a deck around this card instead of using it to tutor up three copies of a pre-established combo piece, notice Intuition is actually much better as a double Entomb. Badass #1 + Badass #2 + Unburial Rites, for example. If you're worried about getting the wrong thing in the graveyard, consider including a Phantasmago... (see all)

posts.post_content: I think it says something about blue that the most powerful deck ever to use this card simply played it as a 3 mana Demonic Tutor. The Tolarian Academy decks, before being banned, could win games on the first turn thanks to this card, Mox Diamond, Mana Vault, Twiddle, Mind over Matter, Time Spiral, Windfall, and Stroke of Genius. Rather than get combinations, the Intuition player would simply find three copies of whatever spell they wanted and make the opponent give them one.
posts.html:
I think it says something about blue that the most powerful deck ever to use this card simply played it as a 3 mana Demonic Tutor. The Tolarian Academy decks, before being banned, could win games on the first turn thanks to this card, Mox Diamond, Mana Vault, Twiddle, Mind over Matter, Time Spiral, Windfall, and Stroke of Genius.
